title: Using the induction method, how can you prove that n^4-4n^2 is divisible by 3 for all n>=2? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let [math]P(n)=n^4-4n^2[/math] As it is given, [math]n\ge 2[/math] Let's check for [math]n=2,[/math] [math]P(2)=2^4-4×2^2=16-16=0[/math] So [math]3\mid P(2),[/math] so it's true for [math]P(2)[/math] Now for induction step we will assume it's true for [math]n=k,[/math] [math]P(k)=k^4-4k^2[/math] Now we will prove its true for [math]n=k+1,[/math] [math]P(k+1)=(k+1)^4-4 (k+1)^2[/math] [math]=\underbrace{k^4}_{(1)}+4k^3+6k^2+4k+1-\underbrace{4k^2}_{(2)}-8k-4[/math] [math]=\underbrace{k^4-4k^2}_{P(k)}+4k^3-4k+6k^2-3[/math] [math]=P(k)+4k(k^2-1)+3(2k^2-1)[/math] [math]=P(k)+\underbrace{4k(k-1)(k+1)}_{4(k-1)k(k+1)}+\underbrace{3(2k^2-1)}_{\text{multiple of 3 }}[/math] The first is true as per our assumption, second term is product of three consecutive numbers which ensures it to be divisible by [math]3[/math] and third term is having [math]3[/math] as one of the factor. Hence, [math]3\mid P(k+1)[/math] Q.E.D. [math]\quad \blacksquare[/math]

[math]\text{The result is true for n = 1}[/math] [math]n^4 - 4 n^2 = 1 - 4 = -3\quad 3\,|\,(-3)[/math] [math]\text{The result is also true for n = 2}[/math] [math]n^4 - 4 n^2 = 2^4 - 4 (2^2) = 0\quad 3\,|\, 0[/math] [math]\text{Let the result be true for n = k, that is}[/math] [math]3\,|\, k^4 - 4 k^2[/math] [math]\text{we need to prove that the result is also true for n = k + 1, that is}[/math] [math]3\,|\, (k + 1)^4 - 4 (k + 1)^2[/math] [math](k + 1)^4 - 4 (k + 1)^2 = k^4 + 4 k^3 + 6 k^2 + 4 k + 1 - 4 (k^2 + 2 k + 1)[/math] [math]=k^4 + 4 k^3 + 2 k^2 - 4 k - 3[/math] [math]= (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 k^3 + 6 k^2 - 4 k - 3[/math] [math]= (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 k^3 - 4 k  + 6 k^2 - 3[/math] [math]= (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 k (k^2 - 1) + 3 ( k^2 - 1)[/math] [math]= (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 k (k - 1) (k +1) + 3 ( k^2 - 1)[/math] [math]= (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 (k - 1)(k) (k +1) + 3 ( k^2 - 1)[/math] [math]\text{by our assumption}[/math] [math]3\,|\, k^4 - 4 k^2\qquad \text{also}\qquad 3\,|\, 4 (k - 1)(k) (k +1)[/math] [math]\because\,\,\text{ (k - 1)(k) (k +1) is a product of three consecutive integers and is divisible by 3.}[/math] [math]\implies\,\,3\,|\, (k^4 - 4 k^2) + 4 (k - 1)(k) (k +1) + 3 ( k^2 - 1)[/math] [math]\implies 3\,|\, (k + 1)^4 - 4 (k + 1)^2[/math] [math]\therefore\,\,\text{the result is also true for n = k + 1. Hence by the principle of}[/math] [math]\text{mathematical induction the result is true for all n}\in\Z^{+}[/math] [math]\text{Please note that the result is also true for n= 0 and for all negative integers.}[/math] [math]\therefore\,\,\text{The result is true for all integers.}[/math]
